Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deciphering the Structure and Kinematics of Active Galactic Nuclei with Reverberation Mapping
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative project is to continue an on-going and successful program of frequent monitoring of the variability in quasar continuum emission and the response of the characteristic broad emission lines to those variations. This provides a probe of the size of the emitting regions, their velocities via the line profiles, and allows an estimate of the mass of the central super-massive black hole. This "reverberation mapping" method is the primary way of measuring the masses of black holes in the central regions of active galaxies out to high redshifts.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students, and postdocs. Public outreach includes involvement in the COSMOS high school summer science teaching program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The method of reverberation mapping or echo mapping is used to study the structure of the central environments around supermassive black holes in active galaxies (galaxies in which the central black hole is growing by swallowing or "accreting" gas from a surrounding disk).  Light originating from the central, hot portion of the accretion disk "echoes" or "reverberates" off of diffuse gas clouds orbiting at larger distances from the black hole, which then glow in spectral lines of various elements contained in the clouds. By monitoring the temporal changes in the brightness of the central disk as well as the subsequent changes in the brightness of the  spectral lines echoing from the more distant clouds, it is possible to map out the size and structure of the emission region, to obtain information on the state of motion of the clouds surrounding the black hole (to determine whether they are orbiting, infalling toward the black hole, or outflowing away from the center), and to determine the mass of the central black hole itself. Reverberation mapping data can probe structures that are only a few light-days from the central black hole, even within galaxies that are hundreds of millions of light-years distant. Results from reverberation mapping provide the fundamental calibration of methods used to determine the growth history of supermassive black holes from the first billion years after the Big Bang until the present.

This project involved a major reverberation mapping effort carried out at Lick Observatory in California in the Spring of 2011, led by a team based at several campuses of the University of California system. Our team was allocated the largest block of nights ever awarded to a single observing program at the Lick Shane 3-meter telescope for this work in 2011, and further observing time in 2012. During the course of this project our team's observations produced some of the highest-quality reverberation mapping data seen to date.  The results of our group's work led to successful measurements of reverberation signatures in nine nearby active galaxies. One example is the galaxy Markarian 50, where we find evidence for a black hole with mass of 37 million solar masses, and our observations indicate that the motions of gas clouds are consistent with disk-like rotation within the inner 10 light-days around the black hole.  Another outcome of our work is the first-ever successful measurement of reverberation from spectral lines of iron, which contribute substantially to the light from some active galaxies. Our observations demonstrate that the spectral lines from iron are produced by clouds at larger distances from the black hole than spectral lines from hydrogen, solving a long-standing puzzle of where in the black hole environment these iron spectral lines originate and confirming recent theoretical predictions for the structure of the emission regions.

Our team invested a major effort into development of new methods for analysis of reverberation mapping data, including new software for disentangling the spectral contributions to the data from different physical components and regions within the galaxy, software for automated measurement of accurate light curves using heterogeneous data from multiple different telescopes and cameras, and new methods for carrying out simulations and modeling of the structure and motions of gas clouds orbiting the black hole and the time-varying spectral line emission from these clouds. We anticipate that the new data analysis methods developed by our collaboration will become widely used by other groups pursuing reverberation mapping work at other observatories.

Our project additionally provided training in astronomical observing and data analysis methods to several graduate and undergraduate students at UC Irvine and other campuses.
